1  MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES
2  INTRODUCTION
3 No fewer than seven of the nine individual plaintiffs in this would-be class action bring
4 strip search claims that fail as a matter of law.  Four of these seven were arrested for crimes of
5 violence:  causing serious bodily harm to a peace officer (Jonah Zern); spousal battery or battery
6 in a dating relationship (Marcie Corneau); battery and threats to commit a crime resulting in
7 death or great bodily injury (Alexis Bronson); and assault with a deadly weapon (Lisa
8 Giampaoli).  Such crimes of violence justify a strip search under both federal and state law.  Two
9 more plaintiffs were arrested for non-violent felonies—felony vandalism (Mary Bull), and
10 burglary and forgery (Laura Timbrook)—and cannot pursue their claims under Section 4030 of
11 the California Penal Code because that statute explicitly excludes felony arrestees from its reach.
12 Finally, all claims raised by the seventh plaintiff challenged here, Charli Johnson, are time-
13 barred.
14 The City therefore respectfully requests that this Court enter summary judgment against
15 Plaintiffs Zern, Corneau, Bronson and Giampaoli on Counts One, Three and Four of the Cross-
16 Complaint, in which they allege that they were strip searched in violation of the state and federal
17 constitutions and Penal Code Section 4030.  The City is also entitled to summary judgment
18 against Plaintiffs Bull and Timbrook on their strip-search claims under Section 4030 of the
19 California Penal Code, and against Plaintiff Johnson on all claims.
20  STATEMENT OF FACTS
21 A.  Jonah Zern
22 Plaintiff Jonah Zern was arrested in San Francisco on January 18, 2003, for violations of
23 Penal Code Sections 594(a)(1) (malicious vandalism), 594(b)(1) (felony vandalism), 148
24 (resisting arrest), and 148.10 (resisting arrest resulting in serious bodily injury to police officer).
25 See San Francisco Police Department ("SFPD") Incident Report and Field Arrest Card of Jonah
26 Zern ("Zern Arrest Rpt.") at 1, 10, attached as Exhibit ("Ex.") A to the Declaration of Ingrid M.
27 Evans In Support Of Defendants’ Motion For Summary Judgment ("Evans Decl.").  Zern was
28 participating in an anti-war protest and traveling on foot through the financial district of San
Defs’. Motion for Summary Judgment 1 N:\LIT\LI2004\031697\00227884.DOC
USDC No. C03-1380 CRB (EMC)

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 92-1     Filed 03/05/2004     Page 4 of 12(cid:10)
1 Francisco.  See Zern Arrest Rpt. at 3, ¶1.  Zern was part of a group that was breaking windows
2 and spray painting buildings along Sansome and Washington Streets.  Id. at 3, ¶2.
3 Inspector Yu, Officer Lozada, and Officer Peagler observed the group of protestors stop
4 in front of the Immigration and Naturalization Services (INS) building, break the glass, and
5 vandalize the building with spray paint.  Id.  The Officers then witnessed a smaller group—
6 consisting of Zern and eight to ten others—knock over four to five San Francisco Police
7 Department motorcycles.  Zern Arrest Rpt. at 3, ¶ 3.  Zern and the small group then kicked and
8 pushed at the leveled motorcycles to the applause of the larger group.  Zern and two others
9 continued their assault by kicking down several newspaper receptacles.  Id.
10 The officers then moved in to arrest Zern and another unidentified male.  As Officer
11 Peagler struggled with the unidentified male, Officer Lozada displayed his star and moved in to
12 arrest Zern.  Zern Arrest Rpt. at 3 ¶ 4; 5, ¶ 3.  Officer Lozada shouted "Police Officer.  Stop.
13 You are under arrest."  Zern disregarded this command and attempted to flee.  Id. at 5, ¶ 4.
14 Officer Lozada then applied a takedown technique that brought Zern onto his back on a parked
15 vehicle, but Zern violently resisted arrest.  Id.  Officer Lozada then brought Zern to the ground
16 and attempted to handcuff him, but a group of twenty or more violent protestors physically
17 attacked Officer Lozada in an attempt to obstruct Officer Lozada's lawful custody of Zern.  Id. at
18 5, ¶¶ 4-5.
19 Inspector Yu and Officer Peagler moved through the crowd to aid Officer Lozada in
20 regaining control of the resisting Zern.  Zern Arrest Rpt. at 3, ¶ 5; 5, ¶¶ 3-6.  Zern continued to
21 resist violently until Officer Peagler placed Zern in a cross face lock.  Then, at the direction of
22 Lieutenant Crenshaw and with the assistance of Inspector Yu, Officers Lozada and Peagler
23 dragged Zern out of the crowd and placed Zern in handcuffs.  Id. at 4, ¶ 5.  Officer Peagler
24 placed Zern in the Sheriff's van and Inspector Yu booked him at the Southern Police Station.  Id.
25 at 4, ¶¶ 5-7.  Among other charges, Zern was arrested for violating Penal Code Section 148.10
26 (resisting arrest resulting in serious bodily injury to police officer).  Evans Decl. ¶2.

B.  Marcie Corneau
1
Plaintiff Marcie Corneau was arrested in San Francisco on September 1, 2003, for an
2
outstanding warrant and a violation of Penal Code Section 243(e)(1) (battery of a spouse or in a
3
dating relationship).  See SFPD Incident Report and Field Arrest Card of Marcie Corneau
4
("Corneau Arrest Rpt.") at 1, 12, attached as Ex. B to Evans Decl.  Corneau and Camio Scott
5
were both from southern California and new to the San Francisco Bay Area.  Corneau Arrest Rpt
6
at 4, ¶ 1.  They were co-habitants in a dating relationship and had a child.  Id. at 3, ¶ 7.
7
On September 1, 2003, Corneau found Scott at a party near 500 Broadway, San
8
Francisco, and the two began to argue outside.  Corneau Arrest Rpt. at 3, ¶¶ 1, 4-5.  Officers
9
Choy and Byrne were walking on Broadway when they observed two people in a verbal
10
argument.  Id. at 3, ¶ 1.  The officers observed both Corneau and Scott swinging their hands at
11
each other.  Id.  Then Scott tried to walk away from Corneau, but Corneau ran at Scott from
12
behind and grabbed his shirt.  Id.  Scott then broke free and continued to walk away until
13
Corneau caught up with him again and, this time, kicked Scott in the upper leg area from behind.
14
Id.  Scott kicked back at Corneau and Corneau stumbled.  Id.  Corneau then again ran at Scott
15
from behind and grabbed his shirt. Id.  At that point, the officers intervened and detained
16
Corneau and Scott pending further investigation.  Id. at 3, ¶ 2.
17
The officers determined Corneau to be the aggressor and, based on their own personal
18
observations, confirmed Scott's version of the incident.  Corneau Arrest Rpt. at 3, ¶¶ 6-7.  Scott
19
was released, and he subsequently filed for a citizen’s arrest against Corneau.  Id. at 8; 3, ¶ 7.
20
Officer Byrne then served Corneau with an Emergency Protective Order.  Id. at 9; 3-4, ¶ 9.  A
21
computer check revealed that Corneau had an outstanding warrant for her arrest and that the
22
couple had had numerous previous domestic disputes.  Id. at 7; 3, ¶ 8; 4 ¶ 1.  Sergeant Venderbilt
23
approved the booking of Corneau, as there was a reasonable likelihood that the safety of both
24
persons would be imminently endangered if Corneau were released.  Id. at 4, ¶ 1.  Corneau was
25
booked for a violation of Penal Code § 243(e)(1) (battery of a spouse or in a dating relationship),
26
a crime of violence.  Evans Decl. ¶3.
27
28

C.  Alexis Bronson
1
Plaintiff Alexis Bronson was arrested in San Francisco on August 5, 2002, for violations
2
of Penal Code Sections 422 (threat to commit crime resulting in death or great bodily injury to
3
another), 242 (battery), and 647(f) (public intoxication).  SFPD Incident Report and Field Arrest
4
Card of Alexis Bronson ("Bronson Arrest Rpt.") at 1, 8, attached as Ex. C to Evans Decl.
5
Officers Doyle and Nelson were dispatched to 680 Mission Street to investigate a reported
6
battery.  Bronson Arrest Rpt. at 3, ¶ 1.  Victim Woody Wilcox met the officers and informed
7
them that he had seen Bronson enter the apartment's parking garage in his car in an unsafe
8
manner and at a high rate of speed.  Id. at 3, ¶ 2.  Wilcox reported that, when he approached
9
Bronson and questioned him about his speed, Bronson became violent and pushed Wilcox in the
10
chest.  Id.  Wilcox then told Bronson that he was going to call 911 to report the incident, and
11
Bronson responded, "If you call 911, I'll kill you."  Id.  The parking lot attendant was able to
12
identify Bronson through his vehicle license plate number and furnished the officers with
13
Bronson's apartment number.  Id.
14
The officers then went to Bronson's apartment with Wilcox and the building manager,
15
Michelle Lee.  Bronson Arrest Rpt. at 3, ¶ 3.  The officers smelled alcohol on Bronson and
16
concluded that he was inebriated, evidencing red eyes and slurred speech.  Id.  Bronson admitted
17
having an argument with Wilcox, but denied the battery.  Id.  Officer Doyle informed Bronson
18
that he would be making a report and provided Bronson with a follow-up form.  Id.
19
The officers returned to the building lobby with Lee.  Bronson followed them into the
20
lobby, and angrily questioning Lee as to why she gave the police his name and apartment
21
number.  Bronson Arrest Rpt. at 3, ¶ 4, Ex. C.  Bronson's menacing manner frightened Lee and
22
corroborated Wilcox's earlier statements about Bronson's actions.  Id.  The officers then arrested
23
Bronson.  Id.  Bronson became belligerent during handcuffing and resisted Officer Doyle's
24
attempts to escort him out of the lobby.  Id.  Once he reached the sidewalk, Bronson lunged
25
towards Officer Nelson, and Officer Doyle had to pull him away.  Id. at 3-4,¶ 4.
26
Officer Miranda assisted Officer Doyle in placing Bronson—who was still violently
27
resisting and out of control—into the police transport, in which Bronson rode to County Jail
28

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 92-1     Filed 03/05/2004     Page 7 of 12(cid:10)
1 No. 9.  Bronson Arrest Rpt. at 4, ¶ 1.  Wilcox then filed a citizen’s arrest form based on the
2 initial threat and battery.  Id. at 4, ¶ 3.  Bronson was booked for violations of Penal Code
3 Sections 422 (threat of death or great bodily injury to another) and 242 (battery), both crimes of
4 violence.  Evans Decl. ¶ 4.
5 D.  Lisa Giampaoli
6 Plaintiff Lisa Giampaoli was arrested in San Francisco on July 20, 2002, for a violation
7 of Penal Code Section 245(a)(1) (assault with a deadly weapon other than a firearm).  See SFPD
8 Incident Report and Field Arrest Card of Lisa Giampaoli ("Giampaoli Arrest Rpt.") at 1, 9,
9 attached as Ex. D to Evans Decl.  On that date at approximately 1:41 a.m., Officers Brothers and
10 Leung witnessed a white male with a dog, followed by a white female, running across the 5100
11 block of Geary Street.  Giampaoli Arrest Rpt at 4, ¶ 1.  The officers pulled over to investigate
12 and were told by Vladimir Mikshansky that he had witnessed Giampaoli urging her dog to attack
13 three Asian males.  Id. at 4, ¶ 2.  This report was corroborated by witnesses Anton Karbushev
14 and Andrew Siri.  Id. at 4, ¶ 5; 5 ¶ 1.
15 Mikshansky described how the Asian males had run inside 5120 Geary Street in order to
16 seek protection from Giampaoli and her attacking dog, and that Mikshansky and another had
17 held the door shut to prevent Giampaoli and her dog from entering that building.  Id. at 4, ¶ 2.
18 After Giampaoli turned to walk away from the door, Mikshansky went back outside.  Id.  But
19 once he did, Giampaoli turned the dog to face Mikshansky, shouting "It doesn't matter if you’re
20 Black, Asian or White," and sicced the dog on Mikshansky.  Id.  The dog bit Mikshansky in the
21 left hand, injuring him.  Id.  Mikshansky stated that, after the dog bit him, he ran across the
22 street, pursued by Giampaoli and the dog.  Around this time, the officers arrived and witnessed
23 the dog and Giampaoli running across the street.  Id.
24 The officers verified that the wound to Mikshansky was consistent with a dog bite.  Id.
25 Giampaoli was arrested for a violation of Penal Code § 245(a)(1) (assault with a deadly weapon
26 other than a firearm), a crime involving violence and the use of a weapon.  Evans Decl. ¶ 5.
27
28
Defs’. Motion for Summary Judgment 5 N:\LIT\LI2004\031697\00227884.DOC
USDC No. C03-1380 CRB (EMC)

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 92-1     Filed 03/05/2004     Page 8 of 12(cid:10)
E.  Mary Bull
1
Plaintiff Mary Bull was arrested and booked on two charges of felony vandalism
2
pursuant to Penal Code Sections 594(b)(1) and 594.2(a).  Evans Decl. ¶ 7 & Ex.F.
3
F.  Laura Timbrook
4
Plaintiff Laura Timbrook was taken into custody on the basis of arrest warrants from the
5
Palo Alto and Berkeley Police Departments for violations of Penal Code Sections 459 (burglary),
6
470(b) (forgery), 476a (insufficient fund check) and 475(a) (forgery).  Evans Decl. ¶ 8 & Ex. G.
7
The warrant issued by the Palo Alto Police Department was a felony warrant.  Id.
8
G.  Charli Johnson
9
Plaintiff Charlie Johnson was arrested in San Francisco on August 30, 2001, on an
10
outstanding bench warrant for a violation of Vehicle Code § 14601.1(a) (operating a vehicle on a
11
suspended license).  Evans Decl. ¶6 & Ex. E.
12
13
 ARGUMENT
14
I.  SUMMARY JUDGMENT MUST BE GRANTED WHERE, AS HERE, THE
15
UNDISPUTED MATERIAL FACTS ENTITLE DEFENDANTS TO JUDGMENT
AS A MATTER OF LAW.
16
A moving party is entitled to summary judgment if there is no genuine issue as to any
17
material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.  Fed. R. Civ. P.
18
56(c).  Material facts are those which may affect the outcome of the case.  Anderson v. Liberty
19
Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986).  The moving party bears the initial burden of production
20
demonstrating the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.  Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S.
21
317, 323 (1986).  The party opposing the motion may not rest on conclusory allegations or mere
22
assertions, but must come forward with probative evidence that is sufficient, taking the record as
23
a whole, to allow a rational jury to find for the nonmoving party.  Matsushita Electric Industries
24
Co. v. Zenith Radio, 475 U.S. 574, 587 (1986).
25
Here, there are no material facts in dispute:  the nature of the charges against each of the
26
plaintiffs is clearly documented and the date of Plaintiff Johnson’s arrest is similarly beyond
27
28
Defs’. Motion for Summary Judgment 6 N:\LIT\LI2004\031697\00227884.DOC
USDC No. C03-1380 CRB (EMC)

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 92-1     Filed 03/05/2004     Page 9 of 12(cid:10)
1 dispute.  As these uncontested facts dispose of claims raised by seven of the nine individual
2 plaintiffs as a matter of law, Defendants are entitled to summary judgment.
3 II.  BECAUSE PLAINTIFFS ZERN, CORNEAU, BRONSON AND GIAMPAOLI
WERE ARRESTED FOR CRIMES OF VIOLENCE, THEIR CONSTITUTIONAL
4 CLAIMS FAIL AS A MATTER OF LAW.
5 The Supreme Court of the United States has held that the Fourth Amendment of the
6 United States Constitution protects an arrestee's privacy interests and bars intrusions into the
7 body which are not justified under the circumstances.  Schmerber v. California, 384 U.S. 757,
8 768 (1966).  In determining whether a search was reasonable under the Fourth Amendment, a
9 court must balance "the need for the particular search against the invasion of personal rights that
10 the search entails."  Bell v. Wolfish, 441 U.S. 520, 559 (1979).
11 The case law could not be clearer:  a strip search is reasonable and justified if the charged
12 offense is related to drugs, weapons or violence.  See Kennedy v. Los Angeles Police Dep't, 901
13 F.2d 702, 716(9th Cir. 1990); Thompson v. City of Los Angeles, 885 F.2d 1439, 1447 (9th Cir.
14 1989); Giles v. Ackerman, 746 F.2d 614, 618 (9th Cir. 1984); see also Masters v. Crouch, 872
15 F.2d 1248, 1255 (6th Cir. 1989); Dufrin v. Spreen, 712 F.2d 1084, 1087 (6th Cir. 1983);
16 Dobrowolskyj v. Jefferson County, 823 F.2d 955, 958-59 (6th Cir. 1987).
17 Controlling Ninth Circuit decisions also leave no doubt that the offenses for which
18 Plaintiffs Zern, Corneau, Bronson and Giampaoli were arrested all qualify as crimes of violence.
19 For example, in United States v. Robinson, 967 F.2d 287, 293 (9th Cir. 1992), the Ninth Circuit
20 explained that, in the sentencing context, “crimes of violence” contain an element of use,
21 attempted use, or threatened use of physical force against another or involve conduct which
22 poses a serious risk of potential injury to another.  Id.  Plaintiff Zern’s arrest for resisting arrest
23 with significant bodily injury to a peace officer easily satisfies this test, as do the arrests of
24 Plaintiffs Corneau and Bronson for battery and Plaintiff Giampaoli for assault with a deadly
25 weapon.  See id. (battery on a police officer is a crime of violence); United States v. Campos-
26 Fuerte, 357 F.3d 956, 961 (9th Cir. 2004) (flight from police in willful and wanton disregard for
27 safety a crime of violence); Rosales-Rosales v. Ashcroft, 347 F.3d 714, 717 (9th Cir. 2003) (threat
28 to commit crime resulting in death or great bodily injury to another is crime of violence); United
Defs’. Motion for Summary Judgment 7 N:\LIT\LI2004\031697\00227884.DOC
USDC No. C03-1380 CRB (EMC)

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 92-1     Filed 03/05/2004     Page 10 of 12(cid:10)
1 States v. Amparo, 68 F.3d 1222, 1225 (9th Cir. 1995) (assault and battery are each crimes of
2 violence).
3 As each of these Plaintiffs was charged with one or more crimes of violence, a strip
4 search was an objectively reasonable procedure in each case.  These Plaintiffs’ claims of
5 constitutional violations fail as a matter of law.
6 III.  THE CLAIMS OF PLAINTIFFS BULL, ZERN, CORNEAU, BRONSON,
GIAMPAOLI AND TIMBROOK UNDER PENAL CODE SECTION 4030 FAIL
7 AS A MATTER OF LAW BECAUSE THEY WERE EACH ARRESTED FOR A
FELONY AND/OR CRIME OF VIOLENCE.
8
All individual plaintiffs also bring claims for strip searches that allegedly violate
9
California Penal Code Section 4030.  But this statute specifically excludes from its provision any
10
persons arrested for a felony.  The statute states:
11
The provisions of this section shall apply only to prearraignment detainees
12 arrested for infraction or misdemeanor offenses and to any minor detained
prior to a detention hearing on the grounds that he or she is a person . . . .
13 alleged to have committed a misdemeanor or infraction offense.  (Cal.
Penal Code § 4030.)
14
Section 4030 also provides that reasonable suspicion is required to strip search certain persons
15
arrested for misdemeanors and infractions “except those involving weapons, controlled
16
substances or violence.”  Penal Code § 4030(f) (emphasis added).
17
Plaintiffs Mary Bull and Laura Timbrook were each arrested on felony charges.  See
18
Evans Decl. ¶¶ 7-8.  As shown above, Plaintiffs Zern, Corneau, Bronson and Giampaoli were
19
arrested for crimes of violence.  See Section II, supra.  Accordingly, none of these plaintiffs are
20
entitled to invoke Penal Code Section 4030, and Defendants are entitled to summary judgment
21
on those claims.1
22
IV.  PLAINTIFF JOHNSON’S CLAIMS ARE TIME-BARRED.
23
The instant action was filed on April 23, 2003, but Plaintiff Charli Johnson appears for
24
the first time in the First Amended Complaint, filed on January 12, 2004.  Johnson's arrest and
25
the events of which she complains occurred on or about August 30, 2001.  See Evans Decl. ¶6.
26
                                                
1 Lisa Giampaoli’s claim under Penal Code § 4030 is also barred by her failure to file a
27
timely government tort claim.  See Section IV, infra.
28
Defs’. Motion for Summary Judgment 8 N:\LIT\LI2004\031697\00227884.DOC
USDC No. C03-1380 CRB (EMC)

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 92-1     Filed 03/05/2004     Page 11 of 12(cid:10)
1 At the time her claims arose, the statute of limitations for her federal claims was one year.
2 Federal claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 are governed by the applicable state statute of limitations.
3 See Wilson v. Garcia, 471 U.S. 261, 279-80 (1985).  Before January 1, 2003, that statute of
4 limitations was one year.  See Cal. Code Civ. Pro. § 340 (West 1982 [before amendment
5 effective Jan. 1, 2003]); Hacienda Valley Mobile Estates v. City of Morgan Hill, 353 F.3d 651,
6 655 & n.2 ( 9th Cir. 2003).  Accordingly, Johnson was required to file any federal claims by
7 August 30, 2002.  Her 2004 complaint is more than a year too late.
8 Plaintiff Johnson’s state-law claims are likewise time-barred.  “[S]ubmission of a claim
9 to a public entity is a condition precedent to tort action and the failure to present the claim bars
10 the action.”  Lutz v. Tri City Hosp., 179 Cal. App. 3d 807, 812 (1986).  California Government
11 Code section 911.2 requires that a tort claim for personal injury against a public entity be filed
12 “not later than six months after the accrual of the cause of action.”  People ex rel Dept. of
13 Transp. v. Sup. Ct. (Isenhower), 105 Cal. App. 4th 39, 43 (2003).  The state claim presentation
14 requirement applies to claims for monetary relief whether based on tort, contract, statute or state
15 constitutional provisions.  See Baines Pickwick Limited v. City of Los Angeles, 72 Cal. App. 4th
16 298, 309 (1999) (contract and tort claims); Nuremberg Actions v. County of Contra Costa, 697 F.
17 Supp. 1111, 1113 (N.D. Cal. 1988) (state constitutional claims); Gatto v. County of Sonoma, 98
18 Cal. App. 4th 744, 765 (state Unruh Civil Rights Act claims).  Each claimant must file a
19 government claim, and compliance is not excused on the ground that another party filed a
20 government claim based on the same facts or occurrence.  See, e.g., Nguyen v. Los Angeles
21 County Harbor/UCLA Med. Ctr., 8 Cal. App. 4th 729, 734 (1992) (granting nonsuit as to
22 parents’ claim for emotional distress although daughter had filed government claim for damages
23 based on same occurrence).
24 Plaintiffs seek to rely on a class government tort claim filed by Mary Bull on February
25 10, 2003, to satisfy the claim presentation requirement of all named plaintiffs.  The class action
26 procedures do not extend the statute of limitations or the time for complying with the claim
27 presentation requirements.  Thus, in order to rely on the February 10, 2003, claim, each
28 plaintiff’s state law claims must have arisen on or after August 10, 2002.  As Plaintiff Johnson’s
Defs’. Motion for Summary Judgment 9 N:\LIT\LI2004\031697\00227884.DOC
USDC No. C03-1380 CRB (EMC)

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 92-1     Filed 03/05/2004     Page 12 of 12(cid:10)
1 claim arose in August 2001 but she failed to file a government claim within six months, Plaintiff
2 Bull’s class claim, filed a year and a half later, cannot resurrect it.  Plaintiff Johnson’s state law
3 claims, like her federal claims, are time-barred.
4  CONCLUSION
5 Defendants respectfully request that this Court enter summary judgment in their favor on
6 the claims and for the reasons specified above.
7

1  I.  SUMMARY OF PLAINTIFFS' ARGUMENT 
2  Defendants seek what is in effect an advisory opinion on the legality of their new 
3  written strip search and safety cell policies.  At least three reasons should prompt the Court to 
4  deny Defendants' motion. 
First, declaratory relief is inappropriate unless the matter is ripe for adjudication and 
5 
does not require a more factual development of the record.  United States ofA  merica v. Braren, 
6 
338 F.3d 971,975 (9th Cir. 2003); United States. v. State ofrVashington, 759 F.2u 1353, 1357 
7 
(9th Cir. 1985) (en bane); Orix Credit Alliance v.  Wolfe, 212 F.2d 891, 895-896 (5th Cir.2000); 
8 
Robinson Band ofP orno Indians ofR  obinson Rancheria v. Babbitt (N.D. Cal. 1998) 1998 WL 
9 
[Westlaw] 355580 .. In detem1ining the legality of jail policies infringing on arrestees' Fourth 
10 
Amendlnent and Due Process rights, courts must conduct a "delicate balancing" between 
11 
"institutional needs and objectives" and the "constitutional liberties" of persons suspected of 
12 
th 
crime.  Kennedy v. Los Angeles Police Dept., 901 F.2d 702, 711 (9 Cir. 1989).  That balancing 
13 
cannot be done within the confines of the Cross-Complaint in which Defendants seek a 
14 
declaratory judglnent. 
15 
Second, declaratory relief should be denied when it will not terminate the proceedings 
16 
and afford relief from the uncertainty and controversy faced by the parties."  United States. v. 
17 
State of Washington, 759 F.2d 1353, 1357 (9th Cir. 1985) (en bane).  Plaintiffs' claims focus on 
18 
unconstitutional and illegal conduct which in some cases emanated from written policies, but in 
19 
many cases violated written policies but became the de facto policies of the Department. 
20 
Absent a record showing that the Department will enforce the valid new policies, no Order 
21 
should issue and, in any event, no Order will bind those not now before the Court and cannot 
22 
preclude suits by those harmed by unconstitutional practices post-January 2004. 
23 
Finally, many of the new policies are suspect and lack any support in the record. 
24 
Defendants reject the mandatory requirement of individualized reasonable suspicion and create 
25 
broad categories permitting visual body cavity searches of those arrested on weapons, drugs or 
26 
violence charges and with certain criminal histories absent ay showings whatever that such 
27  individuals are, in fact, are likely to secrete weapons or contraband in body orifices when 
28  arrested.

1  II.  OVERVIEW OF PLAINTIFFS' OPPOSITION 
2  On January 22, 2004, seeking to moot Plaintiffs' claims for injunctive relief and 
3  Plaintiffs' Motion for a Preliminary Injunction, Defendants filed a Cross-Complaint for 
Declaratory Relief to which they appended new regulations.  The Department promulgated 
4 
these new policies in mid-January 2004, years after the Ninth Circuit had condemned blanket 
5 
strip searches and nine months after Plaintiffs filed suit.  The Cross-Complaint asks the Court 
6 
to declare that the c1ain1 for injunctive relief is moot and that the new regulations comply with 
7 
federal and state law. 
8 
Defendants' Motion for Judgment on the Pleadings seeks an Order blessing the Sheriffs 
9 
Department's new written policies.  Defendants' Cross-Complaint alleges no more than the 
10 
existence of a dispute between the parties about the legality of the new written policies.  It 
11 
contains no allegations describing the institution's security needs which could support the new 
12 
written policies, fails to allege that the Department has disciplined violators of the prior written 
13 
policies, or even enforced the new ones. 
14 
The issues framed by the Cross-Complaint are simply not ripe for adjUdication.  Those 
15 
issues need further factual development.  United States ofA  merica v. Braren, 338 F.3d 971, 
16 
975 (9th Cir. 2003).  Moreover, many of the issues addressed by new written policies, dealing 
17 
with both visual body searches and particularly safety cells are not encompassed in Plaintiffs' 
18 
pleadings.  Ruling on these matters would be a purely advisory opinion which this Court lacks 
19 
jurisdiction under Article III to issue. 
20 
A review of the Plaintiffs' pleadings in this case reveals that from the start Plaintiffs 
21 
have sought redress for defendants' conduct which violated the rights of Plaintiffs and class 
22 
members protected by the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments and by California statute.  Some 
23 
of that conduct arose from deputies' application of illegal written policies while other abuses 
24 
resulted from systemic violations of written policies so that new de facto policies came into 
25 
effect.  For example, contrary to written policies, authorization forms were altered to create 
26  purported strip search consent forms.  Deputies participated in cross-gender searches, violating 
27  another written policy. And, in contravention of an express safety cell written policy, deputies 
28  used safety cell placements to punish arrestees who had been deemed uncooperative.

1  Promulgation of new written policies, as an isolated act, provides no assurance that the abuses 
2  which prompted this litigation will not continue.  Only an injunction has the potential to create 
3  that beneficial result. 
Defendants assert that their motion carves out an "autonomous" question, distinct from 
4 
the rest of the litigation.  Not so.  Contrary to Defendants' assertion, even a ruling in their favor 
5 
will not preclude litigation by those harmed by unconstitutional conduct of Department 
6 
personnel occurring after January 2004.  Rased on the written policies alone, the Court cannot 
7 
accurately determine whether these written policies "vill actually dictate the practices of jail 
8 
personnel.  The Court should not assume that its approval of the new written policies will 
9 
thwart future litigation.  And, of course, the Court's ruling will not bind future litigants (and of 
10 
course not those within the instant class) allegedly harmed by post January 2004 Department 
11 
practices and de facto policies. A partial judgment on the pleadings for declaratory relief is 
12 
inappropriate here.  Questions of fact about the effect of the new policies on actual practice and 
13 
the factual basis for the new policies mandating blanket strip searches on certain classes of 
14 
arrestees remain to be answered.  Moreover, such an order will not foreclose future litigation 
15 
based, as is the instant case, on illegal Departmental conduct. 
16 
Many of the policies themselves are also suspect.  The Ninth Circuit has condemned 
17 
blanket overbroad policies which consign entire categories to visual body cavity searches in the 
18 
absence of individualized reasonable suspicion.  No Ninth Circuit case has held that officials 
19 
may search pre-arraignment arrestees based solely on the nature of the arrest or on an arrestee's 
20 
criminal history.  Apart from citations to cases which Defendants often misread, Defendants 
21 
offer no basis for consigning entire groups of arrestees to visual body cavity searches absent 
22 
individualized reasonable suspicion. 
23 
While notice pleading rules permitted Defendants to file a barebones Cross-Complaint 
24 
for Declaratory Relief, that pleading, even with the attached new regulations, gives the Court 
25  scant basis on which to enter partial judgment for Defendants.  In determining the legality of 
26  jail policies infringing on arrestees' Fourth Amendment and Due Process rights, courts must 
27  conduct a "delicate balancing" between "institutional needs and objectives" and the 
28  "constitutionulliberties" of persons suspected of crime.  Kennedy v. Los Angeles Police Dept.,

1  901 F.2d 702, 711 (9th Cir. 1989).  That balancing cannot be done within the confines of the 
2  Cross-Complaint in which Defendants seek a declaratory judgment. 
3  To judge the merit of the written policies the Court must go beyond the pleadings to 
determine the justification for the new policies, particularly those permitting strip searches for 
4 
entire classes of individuals.  This task is necessary given the Ninth Circuit's recognition that 
5 
there are "few exercises of state authority that intrude on citizen's privacy and dignity as 
6 
severely as visual anal and genital searches." Fuller v. M.G. Jewelry, 950 F.2d 1437,1445 (9th 
7 
Cir. 1991).  Among the questions which require answers are: What was the jails' history of 
8 
finding weapons and contraband during visual body cavity searches of those arrested under the 
9 
prior policy? Have deputies ever discovered contraband during visual body cavity searches on 
10 
those transferred from other institutions?  What alternative procedures exist to detect weapons 
11 
or contraband short of visual body strip searches?  What information do Sheriff s Department 
12 
personnel possess when deciding whether to subject an arrestee to a visual body cavity search? 
13 
How have Sheriff s Department personnel actually cOlnplied with prior written policies which 
14 
protected arrestees from improper strip searches or placements in safety cells?  Will citizen 
15 
arrests be deemed a valid basis for a strip search?  How does the Sheriff s Department classify 
16 
crilnes of violence? Defendants' papers provide no answers to these questions.  Without the 
17 
answers to these questions, this Court cannot determine if the intrusion on pre-arraignment 
18 
arrestees' rights is warranted given the institution's security needs against which the arrestees' 
19 
rights must be weighed. Absent factual support for the dilution of Fourth Amendment rights 
20 
occasioned by subj ecting arrestees to visual body cavity searches, the Court has an insufficient 
21 
basis on which to judge the constitutionality of the policies.  Pending a more robust 
22 
development of the record, the Court must deny Defendants' motion.  United States ofA  merica

1  ARGUMENT 
2  III.  A PARTIAL JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS ON DEFENDANTS' 
CROSS-COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY JUDGMENT IS 
3  INAPPROPRIATE BECAUSE ISSUES OF FACT MUST BE RESOLVED 
AND BECAUSE A PARTIAL DECLARATORY JUDGMENT WILL 
4  NOT TERMINATE THE CONTROVERSY. 
5  A.  A Judgment On The Pleadings Is Not Warranted If Factual Issues 
Remain To Be Adjudicated. 
6 
"A judgment on the pleadings is properly granted when, taking all allegations in the 
7 
pleading as true, the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law."  Enron Oil 
8 
Trading & Transportation Co. v.  Walbrook Ins. Co., Ltd.,132 F.3d 526,528 (9th Cir. 1997).  "A 
9 
motion for judglnent on the pleadings pursuant to Fed.R.Civ.P. 12(c) is appropriate where the 
10 
material facts of a case are not in dispute, and a judgment on the merits may be achieved by 
11 
focusing on the legal issues and agreed facts in the case.  If the pleadings do not resolve all of 
12 
the factual disputes, a trial is more appropriate than a judgment on the pleadings." Roberts v. 
13 
Rubert v. Ruhrman, Inc. 909 F.Supp. 545, 552 (N.D. Ill. 1995). 
14 
Defendants have alleged absolutely no facts in their Cross-Complaint that the 
15  Department disciplined deputies who formerly violated arrestees' rights, or that deputies have 
16  not and will not violate the rights of those arrested after January 2004.  Plaintiffs would have 
17  denied such allegations and judgment on the pleadings would have been denied ab initio.  On 
18  the other hand, the absence of such allegations provides the Court with no assurance that 
19  adoption of the new written policies will result in protection of arrestees' rights. 
20  The Ninth Circuit has explained, "A court may, however, consider certain materials--
21  documents attached to the complaint, documents incorporated by reference in the complaint, or 
22  matters of judicial notice--without converting the motion to dismiss into a motion for summary 
23  judgment."  United States  v. Ritchie,  342 F.3d 903, 908 (9th Cir. 2003).  Plaintiffs are asking 
the Court to take judicial notice of the exhibits filed in support of Plaintiffs' Motion for a 
24 
Preliminary Injunction. Rule 201, Federal Rules of Evidence, United States v.  Wilson, 631 F.2d 
25 
118, 119 (9th Cir. 1980); Cardiner v. Provident Life And Accident Insurance Company, 158 
26 
F.Supp.2d 1088, 1099 (C.D. Cal. 2001).  Plaintiffs do not ask the Court to accept the testimony 
27 
as tnle, but only to recognize that in papers already before the Court, Plaintiffs allege with 
28

1  supporting documents that Sheriff s Department personnel consistently violated Department 
2  written policies, confirming that factual issues remain to be litigated and that judgment on the 
3  pleadings must be denied. 
4  B.  Declaratory Judgment Must Be Denied When A Party Seeks Only 
An Advisory Opinion, When The Issues Are Not Ripe For 
5  Adjudication Because The Factual Record Is Incomplete If 
Declaratory Relief Will Not Terminate The Controversy. 
6 
This Court may not exercise Article III jurisdiction when a party seeks only an advisory 
7 
opinion.  The Court's "role is neither to issue advisory opinions nor to declare rights in 
8 
hypothetical cases." Thomas v. Anchorage Equal Rights Com'n, 220 F.3d 1134, 1138 (9th Cir. 
9 
2000) (en bane). 
10 
This Court has discretion to deny declaratory relief if prudential considerations dictate 
11 
against it.  Thus, "even if Article III jurisdiction does exist, a court must refrain from issuing 
12  declaratory relief if the matter is not ripe for decision.  A case is not ripe if further factual 
13  development is required."  United States ofA  merica v. Braren, 338 F.3d 971, 975 (9th Cir. 
14  2003); Orix Credit Alliance v. Wolfe, 212 F.2d 891, 895-896 (5th Cir.2000).  The Ninth Circuit 
15  further instructs us that,  "Declaratory relief should be denied when prudential considerations 
16  counsel against its use ... Declaratory relief should be denied when it will neither serve a 
17  useful purpose in clarifying and settling the legal relations in issue nor terminate the 
18  proceedings and afford relief from the uncertainty and controversy faced by the parties." 
19  United States. v. State of Washington, 759 F.2d 1353,1357 (9th Cir. 1985) (en bane).  See, e.g., 
20  Cha-Toine Hotel Apartments Bldg. Corp. v. Shogren, 204 F.2d 256,258 (7 Cir. 1953) (same); 
Miramax Film Corp. v. Abraham 2003 WL 22832384, at 15 (S.D.N.Y. 2003) (same). 
21 
"In fact, the court may, after a full consideration of the merits, exercise its discretion to 
22 
refuse to grant declaratory relief because the state of the record is inadequate to support the 
23 
extent of relief sought."  State of Washington, supra, at  1356.  This Court has refused to grant 
24 
declaratory relief when final relief is dependent on resolution of factual disputes. In Robinson 
25 
Band ofP  omo Indians ofR  obinson Raneheria v. Babbitt (N.D. Cal. 1998) 1998 WL [Westlaw] 
26 
355580, plaintiff sought a declaration that it could legally conduct gaming without government 
27 
permits.  Refusing to grant that relief, this Court explained, "It is unlikely that a declaratory 
28

4  scenarios are lawful."  1998 WL [Westlaw] 355580, at 3. 
5  IV.  THE STATE OF THE RECORD ON DEFENDANTS' MOTION 
PRECLUDES THE GRANT OF DECLARATORY RELIEF. 
6 
The Court cannot gauge the constitutional or statutory validity of the current policies 
7 
absent a balancing of the harsh intrusion into personal privacy effected by a visual body cavity 
8 
search against evidence that such degradations are necessary to safe operation of the jails.  In 
9 
determining the legality of jail policies infringing on arrestees Fourth Amendment and Due 
10 
Process, this Court must conduct a "delicate balancing" between "institutional needs and 
11 
objectives" and the "constitutional liberties" of persons suspected of crime.  Kennedy, supra, 
12  901 F.2d 702, 711 (9th Cir. 1989).  "The permissibility of a particular law enforcement practice 
13  is judged by balancing its intrusion on the individual's Fourth Amendment interests against its 
14  promotion of legitimate governmental interests."  Giles v. Ackerman, 746 F.2d 714, 617 (9th 
15  Cir. 1984) "The more intrusive the search, the closer governmental authorities must come to 
16  demonstrating probable cause will uncover the objects for which the search is being 
17  conducted." Mary Beth G. v. City o/Chicago, 723 F.2d 1263, 1273 (ih Cir. 1983). 
18  Thus, addressing the LAPD's policy of subjecting all felony arrestees to visual body 
19  cavity searches, Kennedy explained that the "critical inquiry is whether the LAPD has a 
20  sufficient justification for imposing its blanket policy."  The Ninth Circuit invalidated the policy 
on the ground that the LAPD had failed to produce, in support of its justification, "any 
21 
documentation (or even assertion) that felony arrestees have attempted to smuggle contraband 
22 
into the jail in greater frequency than misdemeanor arrestees."  901 F2d at 713. 
23 
Plaintiffs remind the Court that those arrestees whose body cavities Defendants wish to 
24 
search have only been arrested, not even arraigned, much less convicted.  In the instant case, 
25 
virtually none of them was charged.  Yet they were subj ect to what the Ninth Circuit has 
26 
described as "dehumanizing and hmniliating" and Hone of the most grievous offenses against 
27 
personal dignity and common decency" the "intrusiveness [of which] cannot be overstated." 
28

& SCHWARTZ

1  901 F.2d at 711.  This dehumanizing experience, then, in effect is the punishment many 
2  arrestees receive solely because they are suspected of committing a crime.  These descriptions 
3  must be given effect or they lose any meaning.  Ifbalanced equally against an amorphous claim 
of jail security, the descriptions of visual body cavity searches as "grievous offenses" or 
4 
"dehumanizing" might as well be morphed into "unpleasant" or "uncomfortable." 
5 
The only way in which the Court can give effect to the accurate harsh descriptions 
6 
affixed to such searches is by requiring Defendants to sustain their heavy burden of factually 
7 
justifying the necessity for these blanket policies.  Defendants have not offered such 
8 
justification and must go outside the confines of their Cross-Complaint to do so.  Based solely 
9 
on the allegations in Defendants' Cross-Complaint and the n~w policies appended to that 
10 
pleading, the Court cannot confidently balance the dilution of Fourth Amendment rights 
11 
wrought by a visible body cavity search against the jails' security interests. Therefore, "The 
12 
state of the record is inadequate to support the extent of relief sought." State of fiVashing tun, 
13 
supra, at 1356.  See, also, Robinson Band ofP orno Indians ofR  obinson Rancheria v. Babbitt, 
14 
supra. 1998 WL 355580, at 3.  The Court therefore must dcny Defendants' ITIotion. 
15 
V.  AN ORDER BLESSING THE NEW REGULATIONS WILL NOT 
16  RESOLVE THE CONTROVERSY BETWEEN THE PARTIES NOR 
PRECLUDE FUTURE LITIGATION; MOREOVER SUBSTANTIAL 
17  UNRESOLVED FACTUAL ISSUES TIED TO THE VALIDITY OF THE 
NEW REGULATIONS FURTHER COUNSEL DENIAL OF THE 
18  MOTION. 
19  A.  Defendants' Motion Mischaracterizes Plaintiffs' Claims. 
20  Defendants support the need for declaratory relief with the following statements: 
In their motion for a preliminary injunction, plaintiffs seek to enjoin 
21 
the current policies and allege an ongoing threat of irreparable harm to 
22  plaintiffs pending trial, despite the fact that they base their complaint in 
this action entirely on now-superseded policies.  Plaintiffs' actual quarrel, 
23 
therefore, is with stale policies that were at one time applied to individuals 
24  who are no longer in the custody of the Sheriff.  A declaration from this 
Court that the current policies fully comply with applicable law will cabin 
25 
the current litigation, which Plaintiffs should not be allowed to expand to 
26  encompass policies that were not yet in force at the time that their claims 
arose. 
27 
28 
CASPER, MEADOWS 
& SCHWARTZ 
~121 N. California Blvd.,  MARY BULL, et aI., v. CITY AND COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO, et 31.  Page 8 
Suite 1020 
lalnu! Creek, CA 94596  USDC Case No. C03-1840 CR~ 
TEL: (92G) 947-1147 
PLAINTIFFS' MEMORANDUM IN OPPOSITION TO MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
FAX (925) 947-1131 

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 124     Filed 03/19/2004     Page 14 of 21(cid:10)
1  Defendants' Memorandum at 6:20-27.  Defendants' characterization of the litigation is just 
2  plain wrong.  Plaintiffs do not base their entire complaint on the "superseded policies." The 
3  First Amended Cross Complaint does not cite a "written policy" as the sole basis for the 
4  Complaint.  While the Motion for Preliminary Injunction addresses some of the old policies, it 
5  asks that the illegal practices of the Sheriffs Department be enjoined.  Examining these 
6  pleadings we find: 
1.  Plaintiffs' First Amended Complaint 
7 
On January 12, 2004, Plaintiffs filed a First Amended Class Action Complaint, adding 
8 
seven additional named Plaintiffs to Ms. Bull and Mr. Zem.  The First Amended Complaint 
9 
does not refer to any particular written policies by number.  It does describe the strip searches 
10 
and, where applicable, the cold room placements of the named Plaintiffs.  The First Amended 
11 
Complaint seeks "declaratory and injunctive relief declaring illegal and enjoining, prelilllinarily 
12 
and permanently, defendants' policies, practices, and customs of subjecting pre-arraignment 
13 
detainees to strip and visual body cavity searches without having a reasonable suspicion that 
14 
such searches would be productive of contraband or weapons and of using the "cold rooms" to 
15 
compel compliance or to punish detainees."  (emphasis added.) 
16 
Though several abuses alleged in the pleadings arose from application of policies as 
17 
written, the pleadings allege many practices and customs in variance with and in violation of 
18 
the written Department policies then in effect such as those forbidding cross-gender searches, 
19 
forbidding use of safely cells to discipline recalcitrant arrestees, and requiring that those in 
20 
safety cells receive safety cell garments.  Again, the allegations did not focus on the "written 
21 
policies," but on the abusive unconstitutional practices which permeated the jail system.  The 
22 
new policies appended to Defendants' Cross-Complaint restate many of the same directives 
23 
which the Department habitually violated, precipitating this litigation. 
24  2.  Plaintiffs' Motion For A Preliminary Injunction 
25  On January 21, 2004, Plaintiffs filed their Motion for Preliminary Injunction to be heard 
26  at the same time as the Motion for Judgment on the Pleadings.  While challenging some of the 
27  Department's written policies (such as strip searching all arrestees who are to be "classified" 
28  and strip searching all arrestees placed in safety cells), the Motion seeks to enjoin the 
CASPER, MEADOWS 
& SCHWARTZ 
2121 N. California Blvd.,  MARY BULL, et aI., v. CITY AND COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO, et al.  Page 9 
Guile 1020 
Walnut Creek, CA 94596  USDC Case No. C03-1840 CRB 
TEL: (925) 947 -114 7 
PLAINTIFFS' MEMORANDUM IN OPPOSITION TO MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
FAX (925) 947-1131 

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 124     Filed 03/19/2004     Page 15 of 21(cid:10)
1  unconstitutional conduct of Department personnel and supervisory officials.  The testimony 
2  supporting Plaintiffs' motion describes a pattern and practice of Department personnel violating 
3  written policies governing visual body cavity searches and the placement of detainees in safety 
4  cells. 1 
B.  A Declaratory Relief Judgment Will Not Resolve The 
5  Controversy Nor Preclude Future Litigation; Additional Facts 
Must Be Resolved Before The Court Can Confidently Decide 
6  Whether Declaratory Relief Is Appropriate. 
The premise of Defendants' motion fails.  Plaintiffs' First Amended Class Complaint 
7 
and Motion for Preliminary Injunction seeks to stop Defendants' illegal practices, both those 
8 
which conform to illegal written policies and those which violate them.  To the extent that 
9 
10 
Plaintiffs have asked the Court to take judicial notice of the First Amended Class Complaint 
11 
and the evidence Plaintiffs have submitted in support of the request for preliminary injunctive relief to 
emphasize the point that Plaintiffs' allegations (supported by Defendants ' testimony) of systemic 
12 
violations of prior written polices create at a minimum the factual question of whether Defendants' 
personnel will adhere to the new policies and whether Defendants' supervisory personnel will enforce 
13 
the policies.  The Court need not accept the truth of this testin10ny, simply the fact that it exists, 
creating at a minimum substantial factual issues which the Defendants' prayed"for Order cannot 
14 
resolve. 
15 
For example, although the written regulations in effect prior to January 2004 required that 
booking strip searches of those falling outside the Strip Search Criteria of Section II of Procedure E-03 
16 
be predicated on the reasonable suspicion that the arrestee possesses contraband and that that 
reasonable suspicion be documented on a written authorization form, Department personnel altered the 
17 
form so that arrestees could "consent" to visual body cavity searches absent meeting the criteria for a 
booking strip search laid out in the Defendants' own policy. Deposition of Richard Dyer, at 54:9-12, 
18 
62:24-64:1; April 11, 2003 Memo to CJ9 Personnel from Captain Richard Dyer, Bull CCSF 00028. 
Mary Bull was asked to sign such a consent form but refused.  Declaration of Mary Bull ~~ 5-7. The 
19 
altered forms were "in common use."  Deposition of Kevin McConnell, 38:22-39:3. 
20 
Although Procedure E-03 required same sex searches, Mary Bull has stated that male deputies 
witnessed her strip search.  Declaration of Mary Bull, ~ 10. 
21 
Procedure E-05 "Safety Cell Use" clearly stated that safety cells were not to be used for 
22 
disciplinary or punitive purposes. Deputy Humphrey stated that it was the practice at CJ9 to place 
prisoners who refuse to consent to a strip search in a safety cell.  Deposition of Suzette Humphrey, at 
23 
82: 14-25, 83: 1.  Mary Bull testified that her refusal to consent to a strip search landed her in a safety 
24  cell twice. Bull Declaration, ~~ 8-11, 13-15. Alexis Bronson has stated that he was placed in a safety 
cell for not coughing loudly enough during a strip search, Miki Mangosing for attempting to talk to her 
friend in an adjacent cell, and Michael Marron for removing a prison-issued wristband. Declaration of 
25 
Alexis Bronson, ~~ 6-7, Declaration of Miki Mangosing, ~~ 3-5, Declaration of Michael Marron, ~~ 4-5. 
26 
While the criteria in the old and new policies mandated strip searches of those charged with 
drugs, weapons or violence, Sheriff s Department employees testified that there was no list of eligible 
27 
charges.  McConnell Deposition, 34:2-6. No evidence exists that actual practices will be different under 
the new written policies. 
28 
CASPER, MEADOWS 
& SCHWARTZ 
2121 N. California Blvd.,  MARY BULL, et aI., v. CITY AND COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO, et al.  Page 10 
SUite 1020 
Walnut Creek, CA 94596  USDC Case No. C03-1840 CRB 
TEL: (925) 947-1147

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 124     Filed 03/19/2004     Page 16 of 21(cid:10)
1  Defendants have in the past and continue to violate constitutional and statutory rights possessed 
2  by arrestees, Defendants will be liable, regardless of the text of the written policies.  Thus, a 
3  declaratory judgment will not resolve claims of arrestees whose rights were or will be violated 
after January 2004.  In any event, even should the Court enter a declaratory judgment, Plaintiffs 
4 
would still be free at trial to prove that deputies consistently violated the Department's written 
5 
policies, both those in effect prior and subsequent to January 2004. 
6 
Shakespeare's observation that "what's past is prologue," (The Tempest, Act II, scene 
7 
1), is truly apt here.  The record before the Court is replete with allegations and evidence of 
8 
violations of prior Department policies which appeared to offer at least some protection to 
9 
arrestees.  Defendants ask the Court to accept on faith that deputies applying the current 
10 
regulations are protecting and will continue to protect arrestees' constitutional and statutory 
11 
rights.  Absent an evidentiary inquiry the Court cannot declare that the new written policies will 
12 
offer any more coverage of arrestees' rights than the "safety garments" sometimes given 
13 
arrestees placed in safety cells.  Even those parts of the new regulations which appear to pass 
14 
constitutional muster may well be honored solely in the breach.  Only a full factual record - not 
15 
Defendants' arguments  will enable the Court to judge whether even those new policies which 
16 
appear facially valid will stand the test oftinle or unfoliunately resel11ble the Enlperor's New 
17 
Clothes. 
18 
Hence, declaratory relief in this case "will neither serve a useful purpose in clarifying 
19 
and settling the legal relations in issue nor terminate the proceedings and afford relief from the 
20 
uncertainty and controversy faced by the parties." State a/Washington, supra, 759 F.2d 1353 at 
21 
1357.  The Court must deny Defendants' motion. 
22 
VI.  DECLARATORY RELIEF ALSO IS INAPPROPRIATE BECAUSE 
23  MANY OF THE NEW WRITTEN POLICIES VIOLATE THE 
CONSTITUTION. 
24 
A.  Visual Body Cavity Searches Are Impermissible Absent 
25  Individualized Reasonable Suspicion That An Arrestee Has 
Secreted Weapons Or Contraband In His Or Her Person. 
26 
The Ninth Circuit has repeatedly used the harshest adjectives in describing the hann 
27 
wrought by body cavity searches carried out by uniformed governnlent officials on naked 
28  detainees.  Giles v. Ackerman, 746 F.2d 714, 617 (9th Cir. 1984) observed that strip searches 
CASPER, MEADOWS 
& SCHWARTZ 
2121 N. California Blvd.,  MARY BULL, et aI., v. CITY AND COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO, et al.  Page 11 
Suile 1020 
Walnut Creek, CA 94596  USDC Case No. C03-1840 CRB 
TEL: (925) 947-1147 
PLAINTIFFS' MEMORANDUM IN OPPOSITION TO MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
FAX (925) 947-1131 

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 124     Filed 03/19/2004     Page 17 of 21(cid:10)
1  caused the "detainee's privacy [to be] invaded in a frightening and humiliating manner." 
2  Kennedy v. Los Angeles Police Dept., 901 F.2d 702, 711 (9th Cir. 1989) concluded that "[t]he 
3  intrusiveness of a body-cavity search cannot be overstated.  Strip searches involving the visual 
exploration of body cavities is dehumanizing and humiliating." Kennedy also noted that '''body 
4 
cavity searches .. [of] inmates represent one of the most grievous offenses against personal 
5 
dignity and common decency.'" ld.  (quoting from Justice Marshall's dissent in Bell v.  Wolfish, 
6 
441 U.S. 558, 576-577 (1979)).  FuLler v. M.G. JeweLry, 950 F.2d 1437,1445 (9th Cir. 1991) 
7 
retnarked that "few exercises of state authority intrude on citizen's privacy and dignity as 
8 
severely as visual anal and genital searches."  These descriptions are more than words cited 
9 
from West's Federal Reporter.  They accurately describe the grave intrusion on Fourth 
10 
Amendtnent protected privacy rights caused by visual body cavity searches. 
11 
Recognizing the grievous character of these intrusions, the Ninth Circuit has condemned 
12 
overbroad blanket strip search policies because such policies do not require the individualized 
13 
reasonable suspicion that the arrestee possesses weapons or other contraband.  Reviewing prior 
14 
decisions, the Ninth Circuit stated in Fuller, supra, that "[t]hese decisions suggest that strip and 
15 
body cavity searches of detainees may be conducted based on reasonable suspicion only where 
16 
such searches are necessary to protect the overriding security needs of the institution--that is, 
17 
where officials have a reasonable suspicion that a particular detainee harbors weapons or 
18 
dangerous contraband."  950 F.2d at 1447.  (emphasis added.)  "[T]he permissibility of a 
19 
particular law enforcement practice is judged by balancing its intrusion on the individual's 
20 
Fourth Amendment interests against its promotion of legitimate governmental interests." Giles 
21 
v. Ackerman, supra, 746 F.2d at 617. 
22 
In explaining application of the reasonable suspicion standard, Kennedy noted that" 
23 
'Reasonable suspicion may be based on such factors as the nature of the offense, the arrestee's 
24 
appearance and conduct, and the prior arrest record.'"  901 F .2d at 716, citing Giles v. 
25 
Ackerman, supra, 746 F.2d at 617.  Kennedy, however, did not state that anyone of these 
26  factors, standing alone, necessarily would give rise to the reasonable suspicion necessary to 
27  justify the strip search.  Hence, "the classification of the offense in some cases might inform the 
28 
CASPER, MEADOWS 
& SCHWARTZ 
2121 N. California Blvd.,  MARY BULL, et aI., v. CITY AND COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO. et al.  Page 12 
SUite 1020 
Walnut Creek, CA 94596  USDC Case No. C03-1840 CRB 
TEL: (925) 947-1147 
FAX (925) 947-1131  PLAINTIFFS' MEMORANDUM IN OPPOSITION TO MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 124     Filed 03/19/2004     Page 18 of 21(cid:10)
1  presence of suspicion, but it does not inform the level of suspicion required." Kennedy, supra, 
2  901 F.2d at 716. 
3  The danger inherent in blanket policies covering an entire classification of individuals is 
4  that it runs the substantial danger of overbreadth, casting many within its net who, if not strip 
searched, will pose no threat to jail security.  Because visual body cavity searches are 
5 
considered "one of the most grievous offenses against personal dignity and common decency 
6 
harm which befalls those subject to such searches" (Kennedy, Y01 F.2d at 711), blanket 
7 
classification should be avoided except when it is narrowly focused.  As Kennedy noted, "a 
8 
ham-handed approach to policy making runs the serious risk of infringing on detainees' 
9 
constitutional rights." 901 F2d at 713. 
10 
B.  With No Factual Basis, The Strip-Search Policies Contain 
11 
Overbroad Classifications And Other Defects Which Preclude 
Declaratory Relief. 
12 
Plaintiffs agree that "[rJeasonable suspicion may be based on such factors as the nature 
13 
of the offense, the arrestee's appearance and conduct, and the prior arrest record" Kennedy, 
14 
supra, 901 F_2d at 716.  Kennedy, however, does not hold that anyone of the factors, standing 
15 
alone, necessarily provides the individualized reasonable suspicion necessary to support the 
16 
intrusion. 
17 
Blanket policies, proffered with no justification, are suspect.  Thus, Kennedy invalidated 
18 
the blanket strip search of all felons on the grounds that the LAPD had failed to produce, in 
19 
support of its justification, "any documentation (or even assertion) that felony arrestees have 
20 
attempted to smuggle contraband into the jail in greater frequency than misdemeanor arrestees." 
21 
901 F.2d at 713. 
22 
Here, Defendants have failed to allege any factual basis demonstrating that the blanket 
23 
classifications are necessary to protect jail security.  No allegation exists in the Cross 
24 
Complaint, for example, that those arrested for drugs, weapons or violence have a propensity to 
25 
secret weapons or contraband in their person.  Mere arrest for an alleged crime involving drugs, 
26 
weapons or violence cannot, without nlore, give rise to a reasonable suspicion that the arrestee 
27 
intends to smuggle contraband into the facility.  As the court noted in Giles v. Ackerman, supra, 
28 
"arrest and confinement in the Bonneville County Jail are unplanned events, so the [strip 
CASPER, MEADOWS 
& SCHWARTZ 
2121 N. California Blvd.,  MARY BULL. et al.. v. CITY AND COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO. et al.  Page 13 
~ulte 10LO 
Walnut Creek, CA 94596  USDC Case No. C03-1840 CRB 
TEL: (925) 947-1147 
PLAINTIFFS' MEMORANDUM IN OPPOSITION TO MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 
FAX (925) 947-1131 

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 124     Filed 03/19/2004     Page 19 of 21(cid:10)
1  search] policy could not possibly deter arrestees from carrying contraband."  746 F.2d at 617. 
2  The question is not whether those arrested for weapons or violence, for example, may pose 
3  sufficient security threats to require particular housing, but whether such individuals, by their 
4  membership in a particular class of arrestees, and regardless of the circumstances surrounding 
the actual arrest, evidence a likelihood that they possess contraband or weapons which can only 
5 
be detected via a visual body cavity search. 
6 
Moreover, the policy Inandating visual body cavity searches of those charged with 
7 
crimes of "violence" is terribly overbroad.  The new policies contain no definition of violent 
8 
crimes.  Thus certain crimes, which n1ay appear to be crimes of violence are not necessarily in 
9 
that category.  For example, battery does not necessarily involve violence, since even the 
10 
slightest touching is sufficient to support a conviction for the offense.  See, e.g., People v. 
11 
Rocha (1971) 3 Ca1.3d 893, 899 ft. 12,92 Cal.Rptr. 172 ("The least unprivileged touching may 
12 
constitute a criminal battery.  'In other words, force against the person is enough, it need not be 
13 
violent or severe."'); People v. Longoria (1995) 34 Ca1.App.4th 12,40 Cal.Rptr.2d 213, ("[t]he 
14 
word 'violence' has no real significance ... ' it has long been established ... that 'the least 
15 
touching' may constitute battery.' " ). 
16 
The absurdity of such blanket classification is evident in the case of Lisa Gialllpaoli. 
17 
Even assuming the charges were true, how can an arrest for allegedly unleashing a dog on 
18 
another person give rise to a reasonable suspicion that the arrestee has placed weapons (i.e. 
19 
another animal) in her body cavity? 
20 
Moreover, the policy makes no distinction between those arrested with probable cause 
21 
and those arrested based on a citizen's arrest.  Hence, those brought into the jails due to 
22 
malicious citizens' complaints by enemies, ex-lovers, etc. and usually released without being 
23 
charged, still must face the harm wrought by a visual body cavity search.  In Corcoran v. 
24 
Fletcher, 160 F.2d 1085 (C.D. Cal. 2001), the court held that a city's policy of substituting 
25 
citizen's arrests for probable cause violated the Fourth Amendment.  Of course, those arrested 
26 
in error for crimes of drugs, weapons or violence also must suffer visual body cavity searches. 
27  The new policies afford no protection for such individuals. 
28 
CASPER, MEADOWS 
& SCHWARTZ 
2121 N. California Blvd.,  MARY BULL, et aI., v. CITY AND COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO, et al.  Page 14 
Suilt: 1020 
Walnut Creek, CA 94596  USDC Case No. C03-1840 CRB 
TEL: (925) 947-1147 
FAX (925) 947-1131  PLAINTIFFS' MEMORANDUM IN OPPOSITION TO MOTION FOR JUDGMENT ON THE PLEADINGS 

Case 3:03-cv-01840-CRB     Document 124     Filed 03/19/2004     Page 20 of 21(cid:10)
1  Similarly no allegations in the Cross-Complaint support the policy that all those arrested 
2  or convicted in the prior five years for crimes involving drugs, weapons or violence must be 
3  subject to a visual body cavity search.  No documentation exists, nor may it exist on a motion 
for judgment on the pleadings, that such arrestees, by virtue of prior arrests or even convictions, 
4 
have a propensity to secret contraband in their orifices.  The same overbreadth taints the policy 
5 
mandating visual body cavity searches of those arrested for probation and parole violations. 
6 
Watt v. City ofR  ichardson Police Department 849 F2d 195,198 (5th Cir, 1988) 
7 
The current written policies are also defective because they make no provision 
8 
excluding those awaiting bail from the visual body cavity search.  Given the recognized 
9 
humiliation of such searches, no reason exists why arrestees should not be given 23 hours to 
10 
post bail and access to a telephone to arrange such release.  Otherwise, a visual body cavity 
11 
search reInains punislunent for those unable to prolnptly post bail.  In the SaIne vein, no one 
12 
eligible for OR release should be strip searched before release on OR has been denied. 
13 
C.  The Safety Cells Policy Is Also Flawed. 
14 
The safety cell policy is defective, too.  No one should be placed in a safety cell unless a 
15 
qualified professional determines that such placement is necessary because the person is a 
16 
danger to himself.  If an arrestee is a danger to others, the arrestee ean be single celled in a 
17 
normal cell.  Moreover, detention in a safety cell must be premised on an individual's particular 
18 
circumstances.  Nonetheless, the perceived danger an individual poses to others provides an 
19 
insufficient basis to strip search an individual laced in a safety cell - once alone, that arrestee 
20 
poses no threat to others.  In any event, no individual should be subjected to a visual body 
21 
search absent an individualized reasonable suspicion that the search is necessary to protect the 
22 
individual. 
23 
Whatever defects may exist in the strip search policy, the main point is this: the Court 
24 
has an insufficient factual record on which to declare the constitutionality of the current 
25 
policies.  For that reason, without more, the Court must refuse to enter judgment approving any 
26  of the current strip policies. 
27 
28

1  VII.  CONCLUSION 
2  Defendants' Motion For Declaratory Relief is not ripe for adjudication.  Assessment of 
3  the new written policies requires a far more factual development than that presented in 
Defendants' papers.  Moreover, the judgment Defendants seek will not terminate the 
4 
controversy.  Defendants offer no assurance that these new policies will be enforced.  More 
5 
significantly, issuance of the Order will not preclude individuals who have been harmed by 
6 
unconstitutional practices from seeking relief.  The Court must deny Defendants' motion for 
7 
judgment on the pleadings.

19

23

24
Plaintiffs are DISMISSED WITH PREJUDICE and the claims of class members are

DISMISSED WITHOUT PREJUDICE.  The statute of limitations for class members’ claims,

which had been tolled during the pendency of this litigation, now commences to run again.

Plaintiffs’ counsel of the outcome of this case by providing them with a copy of this Order.

1 4) If Objector Scott chooses to pursue a claim against named Defendants pursuant to

4 IT IS SO ORDERED.

IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT

CC ORDER RE: MOTIONS FOR
t t  13     v. SUMMARY JUDGMENT
cc aa
ii nini
s Distrs Distr ct of Califorct of Califor1145 CetI aTlY., & COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO,
tete stristri Defendants.
